Friends

class TextureManager

Detailed Description

A class for loading textures from bitmaps. This class is friend to the TextureManager class, and should largely only be used by said class.

Definition at line 71 of file textureManager.h.

int Texture::loadBMP ( std::string  filename  )  [private]

Load a BMP file.

This function heavily based off of a funciton in the book "Computer Graphics Using OpenGL" by F.S. Hill, Jr.

This function takes in a filename, then loads the BMP file given by the filename. It puts all of the pixels for the file into the pixels array. Use with setTexture to get a useful texture out of it. This is a private function which should only be called by TextureManager.

Parameters:
filename is the name of the bitmap file to load.
Returns:
Returns 1 if successful, 0 otherwise.

Definition at line 57 of file textureManager.cpp.

00057                                        {
00058         FILE* infile = NULL;
00059         infile = fopen(filename.c_str(), "rb");
00060         if (!infile) {
00061                 printf("OH NO!\n");
00062                 return 0;
00063         }
00064 
00065         int k, row, col, numPadBytes, nBytesInRow;
00066         char ch1, ch2;
00067 
00068     //This next part reads in some header file information
00069         BMPHeader header;
00070         fread(&header, 14, 1, infile);
00071 
00072     //And this is where we get all of the info that we are actually interested in
00073     BMPInfoHeader infoHeader;
00074     fread(&infoHeader, 40, 1, infile);
00075 
00076         if(infoHeader.bitsPerPixel != 24) {
00077                 printf("Error, should be 24 bits\n");
00078                 fclose(infile);
00079                 return 0;
00080         }
00081 
00082         nBytesInRow = ((3 * infoHeader.nCols + 3)/4) * 4;
00083         numPadBytes = nBytesInRow - 3 * infoHeader.nCols;
00084         numRows = infoHeader.nRows;
00085         numCols = infoHeader.nCols;
00086         pixels = new texRGB[numRows * numCols];
00087 
00088     //Read data in to pixels
00089         long count = 0;
00090         char dum;
00091         for (row = 0; row < numRows; row++) {
00092                 for (col = 0; col < numCols; col++) {
00093                         char r,g,b;
00094                         b = fgetc(infile);
00095                         g = fgetc(infile);
00096                         r = fgetc(infile);
00097                         pixels[count].r = r;
00098                         pixels[count].g = g;
00099                         pixels[count].b = b;
00100                         count++;
00101                 }
00102                 for (k = 0; k < numPadBytes; k++) {
00103                         dum = fgetc(infile);
00104                 }
00105         }
00106         fclose(infile);
00107         return 1;
00108 }

void Texture::setTexture ( GLuint  textureName  )  [private]

Register the texture with OpenGL.

This function heavily based off of a funciton in the book "Computer Graphics Using OpenGL" by F.S. Hill, Jr.

This function sets up the texture information stored in pixels so that a valid texture is created in OpenGL's memory. After creating the texture, releases the memory which was being held by pixels. This is a private function which should only be called by TextureManager.

Parameters:
textureName is a GLuint which will be the identifier for this texture according to OpenGL.

Definition at line 122 of file textureManager.cpp.

00122                                            {
00123     name = textureName;
00124     glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, textureName);
00125     glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_MAG_FILTER, GL_NEAREST);
00126     glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_MIN_FILTER, GL_NEAREST);
00127     glTexImage2D(GL_TEXTURE_2D, 0, GL_RGB, numCols, numRows, 0, GL_RGB, GL_UNSIGNED_BYTE, pixels);
00128 
00129     //Now that we've set the texture, we can actually delete pixels
00130     delete [] pixels;
00131 }
